nodes.bodyText: To me it sounds like a "consumer" rather than a logSource, I would suggest you rename it to HeartBeatConsumer.

nodes.bodyText: you may want to hold on to the set and check if it's empty every time, this will make it future proof for when we add support for dynamic loading.
ahh this is not possible since the other class can only be accessed via tests.
iiuc you just wrapped the result in a Task but did not actually make it asynchronous, so it will block anyway.
Oops sorry about that. Updated
why do use a counter if the thread pool has at most one thread?
pls have this constructor delegate to the one below
hmm so the other constructor is test only and can't be accessed via this
in this case pls change the annotation to @VisibleForTesting so that linter does not complain
if you don't need the indexes, pls use for(Result result: sdkHeartBeatResults)

Even though Tasks.call() is deprecated I suggest you use it as it makes sure that the task actually completes in the face of exceptions and errors, i.e. see b/157690112 for how tasks can hang indefinitely if an exception happens.
use Tasks.forResult(true) ?
why is it a raw Task? should it be Task<Boolean>? also consider renaming the method to something like shouldStoreHeardBeatInfo()

hmm the method itself would storeHeartBeatInformation. It returns a task so that we can wait on the task to complete if needed. The return type doesn't matter in this case but TaskCompletionSource requires a returnType.
in this case use Task<Void>, but raw types break type safety

I wonder what will happen if the device changes timezone, can we use utc here? Additionally getDate() seems deprecated.
Also is it possible that the date is the same but the month is different?
no the date would include a combination of month day and year. Yeah can use utc
what I mean is that date.getDate() returns the day of the month, so there is no info about which month it is or which year
Ah okay I thought it handled all the 3. I will change it.

Regarding the first question, it shouldn't matter if the device changes timezone it should still be utc bcz we are getting the date based on the milliseconds which are the number of milliseconds since epoch (System.getMillis)
From the code below it looks like it's important that this executor is single-threaded, otherwise there will be race conditions, can you pls document it here for our future selves?
Please make these final as well, and in other places in this PR(if any).
consider extracting this formatter into a constant since it never changes.
constants should use CAPS_SNAKE_CASE, pls change throughout
looks like you're updating it inside synchronized, but reading it unprotected, this is a race. consider making this method synchronized as well

hm, actually: are you using this variable to control when to clean up stale heartbeats? if so, is it ok that this variable will not survive app restarts? wouldn't it cause storage to grow in an unbounded manner?
Hmm the method is just restricted for Testing so hadn't made it synchronized.  Hmmm but good catch, maybe it makes sense to put this as well under shared preferences?
what is the purpose of these listeners? why not just use Tasks.await(info.storeHeartBeatInfo(testSdk)) for example?
hmm I used Tasks.await before but it would cause the looper wait issue as there could be more than one threads. Hence the need of the listener similar to what has been done in firebase-installations.
